I can assure the Deputy that the Garda will give every assistance they can, but they cannot be expected to patrol the mountains of Wicklow to ensure that no attacks at all take place.
asked the Minister for Justice if he has received proposals regarding the future of the Garda station at Buttevant, County Cork; and if he will give an assurance that this station will not be closed.

I have received no proposal regarding the future of Buttevant station. A station will be maintained in the town but the existing station is scheduled for replacement and the Office of Public Works have been asked to arrange for the provision of a new station.
asked the Minister for Justice when owners of licensed guns may expect to have them returned.

I assume the Deputy is referring to firearms which were surrendered pursuant to the Firearms (Temporary Custody) Order, 1972. It is necessary, in the public interest, that the surrendered firearms should remain in Garda custody in present circumstances and I am unable to say when it will be possible to return them to their owners.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Medical Card Eligibility.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health whether he will instruct the health boards in the assessment of the means of applicants for medical cards to introduce regulations allowing for (a) the cost of paying hire-purchase instalments on cars (b) transport to work and (c) loan repayments on houses; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr. R. Barry) Richard Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr. R. Barry)
Speaker.P: In assessing eligibility for medical cards all health boards allow, as a deduction from gross income, outgoings on the applicant's house, in excess of £2 per week.

MainHeading.P: Outside the main urban areas health boards also make allowance for reasonable expenses incurred in travelling to and from work. It is a matter for the chief executive officer to determine if, in a particular case, the hire-purchase payments on a car would be allowed as a deduction from income.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly Mr. Barrett Mr. Barrett
Speaker.P: and Mr. Daly asked the Minister for Health if he will take steps to ensure that adequate medical services will be made available to the residents of Sixmilebridge, County Clare, and in the surrounding districts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: The provision of general medical services for persons covered by medical cards in this area is a matter in the first instance for the Mid-Western Health Board. They have tried unsuccessfully to get a doctor who would reside in Sixmilebridge but, as I told Deputies in response to an earlier question, I am informed by the board that the alternative arrangements made for the provision of services for eligible patients in the area are operating satisfactorily.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that people living in this area are finding it almost impossible to get a doctor to come out at night in emergencies, and that there have been several complaints about this matter? Is he aware of that, despite what the Mid-Western Health Board have said?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: The first obligation of the Department of Health and the Mid-Western Health Board is to medical card holders, and my information is that there have been no complaints from medical card holders, in this area.

Would the Parliamentary Secretary consider removing the restriction which prohibits doctors with less than two years' practice from participating under the Health Act, and would he agree that if this were removed it would be far easier to get young doctors to live in the area?
That seems to be a separate question.
Would the Minister have the removal of this restriction considered?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: That is a completely separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will permit medical card holders to choose their own ophthalmic optician in the same way as they can choose their own doctor or pharmacist.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: It is not, at present, my intention to introduce a scheme for a choice of optician by medical card holders. I will, however, keep the matter in mind for consideration at a future date.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Live Animal Experiments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Healy Mr. Healy Mrs. Desmond Mrs. Desmond
Speaker.P: and Mr. Healy asked the Minister for Health if the Government will support the proposal made by the International Association Against Painful Experiments on Animals that the United Nations, through the relevant specialised agency, should establish a research institute for the dual purpose of (a) collating information relating to research techniques not involving the use of live animals for experimental purposes and (b) studying and developing such techniques as may be adopted in wider spheres of medical and scientific research to replace animal tests.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt Mr. Malone Mr. Malone
Speaker.P: and Mr. Kitt asked the Minister for Health if, in view of the increasing public concern regarding the use of live animals for experimental purposes, he will take urgent steps to initiate studies directed towards the development of alternative techniques which could be used to replace experiments on live animals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 10 and 11 together.

MainHeading.P: The use of live animals in experiments is a world-wide practice and the question of establishing a research institute or taking other appropriate steps directed towards the development of alternative techniques to live animal experimentation is one which could only be adequately considered, in so far as a small country such as Ireland is concerned, on an international basis.
Should an international proposal in this matter come before us for consideration I will be prepared to have it sympathetically considered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt Mr. O.J. Flanagan Mr. O.J. Flanagan
Speaker.P: and Mr. Kitt asked the Minister for Health if he will consider banning all tests on live animals in cases where the desired information has already been ascertained or which cannot be shown to be essential for the well-being of mankind, such as those connected with the testing of cosmetic preparations and colouring agents in food, et cetera.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: A person who wishes to carry out an experiment on a live animal for scientific purposes must obtain a licence from the Minister for Health under the Cruelty to Animals Act, 1876.

No experiment may be carried out under the Act except with a view either to the advancement by new discovery of physiological knowledge or of knowledge which will be useful for saving or prolonging life or alleviating suffering, or with a view to the acquisition of such knowledge by persons attending lectures in, for example, medical schools, hospitals or colleges.

All applications for licences and other relevant documents are examined by the medical officers of my Department and I am satisfied that unnecessary experimentation is not being carried out. It would, in my view, seriously frustrate the education of medical and other students if I were to prohibit the use of live animals in experiments carried out for educational purposes. I might mention that only 206 such experiments were carried out in 1972.

MainHeading.P: The great majority of the experiments carried out in Ireland involve rodents only and are done for ensuring the safety of drugs and medicines for use by man; there is no other way of doing this work at present.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that some of those cosmetic preparations are sprayed into the eyes of live animals causing excruciating pain and gross unnecessary cruelty and if other means of testing can be adopted would the Parliamentary Secretary not consider that should be done?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: I would say that was so but in so far as it is possible we will ensure that this pain, or most of it, will not be caused.

I am sure that if some of the ladies who use these cosmetics — and perhaps men in the case of shaving lotions—knew that the preparations were used in experiments causing excruciating pain to live animals they would not be so anxious to buy these products. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to have this matter again examined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: I certainly will, but in this country experiments connected with the testing of cosmetics or colouring agents for food would, as far as we are aware, be very rare indeed.
I am glad to hear that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Moore Mr. Moore Mr. Healy Mr. Healy
Speaker.P: and Mr. Moore asked the Minister for Health the reason for the alarming increase both in the number of experiments performed on living animals in 1972 and in the number of animals used in that year for experimental purposes under the Protection of Animals (Amendment) Act, 1965 as indicated by statistics supplied by his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: The number of experiments carried out on animals in 1972 under the provisions of the Cruelty to Animals Act, 1876, based on returns furnished to the Department by the licensed experimenters, was 79,939. The corresponding figure for 1971 was 69,611.
The number of animals used in these experiments was 34,483 in 1972 compared with 26,285 in 1971.

MainHeading.P: The increases in the number of experiments carried out and of animals used in 1972 were attributable to work done in the Medical Research Council Laboratories and in the Veterinary Research Laboratory in Dublin. The Medical Research Council work was concerned mainly with establishing the safety of drugs used in connection with bacterial diseases and cancer. There is no other way of doing this type of testing at present. The additional Veterinary Research Laboratory work primarily arose out of a special project on “louping ill”, a virus disease of sheep and cattle which is transmissible to humans. The object of the experiments was to devise a speedier diagnostic test. This work has now ceased.

Speaker.P: While we appreciate the need for such experiments, would the Minister consider amending the Act in order that any possible abuse of the freedom given under this Act would be eliminated?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Barry Mr. R. Barry
Speaker.P: I certainly will because, like the Deputy, I should like to see that this thing would not go on.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - County Donegal Old Age Pension.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare why the rate of old age pension granted to a widow in County Donegal (name supplied) is £4 less than the rate of her widow's pension.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Cluskey) Frank Cluskey
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Cluskey)
Speaker.P: The reduction occurred in this case because of the different methods of calculating means derived from capital in these two types of pensions. In this instance the pensioner possessed stock, the market value of which is over £4,000, and she derives an income therefrom of £475 a year.

MainHeading.P: Prior to the year 1963 the same method of assessment was used for both pensions but in November, 1963, provision was made for a more liberal assessment of means derived from capital in the case of a widow. The reason for the change lay broadly in the fact that a high proportion of widows are left with young families and have to face not only a major economic adjustment on the death of the husband but also problems of rearing and educating their children, which do not arise in the case of old age pension claimants.

Speaker.P: While I am well aware that there is a difference in the system of assessing means as between widows and old age pensioners, with the recent easement in the old age pensions' means test one could hardly expect there would be a difference of £4 in the amounts of the two pensions. It is difficult to believe there would be a reduction of as much as £4 when changing from the widow's pension to the old age pension.

The Deputy has raised two points. The widow's pension which this lady was first awarded in May, 1973, was £1.15 and this was increased to £5.15 as a result of the recent budget. The Deputy should be aware that there has been no change in what was awarded and payable in May until the recent reassessment. The system of calculating the rate payable is the system that was adjusted in favour of widows in 1963.

I am aware of that and I answered many questions in regard to it. But does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that there must have been a means assessment for the widow's pension in the first instance which entitled her to £5.15 and on changing over to the old age pension in respect of which the Parliamentary Secretary has been boasting that he eased the means test——
This is an injection of argument. We cannot debate the matter now.
She still should not lose as much as £4. Would the Parliamentary Secretary say if the case has been finalised?

Yes, it has. The pension was calculated and first awarded to this lady on 31st May, 1973. This calculation was done under the system in operation when the Deputy was Minister for Social Welfare. Her widow's pension, under that assessment, was £1.15 per week. As a result of the provisions in the budget that was increased to £5.15 per week. As the Deputy is aware, since 1963 there has been a different means of assessing widows' and old age pensions in favour of widows.
Will the Parliamentary Secretary——
We have devoted a lot of time to the subject. One final, brief supplementary question.
This is very important.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: It was important when we were in Opposition and I asked many questions——
Order. Let us get on with the business of Question Time.

A final supplementary — is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that his colleague now sitting immediately on his right announced, in my presence, in Monaghan, recently that you can now have £4,000 and still get the full old age pension.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: Which is correct.
This lady, in fact, has stock valued at £4,625.
She was nailed. She loses £4.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Letterkenny Social Welfare Information Office.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if a social welfare information office has been opened in Letterkenny, County Donegal; and, if so, if he will state the opening date.
An office to provide the public with information and advice concerning all the services for which my Department is responsible was opened in Letterkenny Employment Exchange on 17th October, 1973.
Were extra accommodation and staff provided for this office by the Parliamentary Secretary?

The accommodation and staff are considered adequate. There appeared on 23rd November a Department advertisement in the Donegal Democrat mentioning the lady in charge of the information centre with her address and telephone number.
Was this a new appointment?
The information centre was an innovation.
Was it a new appointment?
I am not sure if it was a new appointment. It would not be someone newly appointed since it would be desirable that it should be somebody familiar with the operation of the Department.

That is what I mean. Is the Parliamentary Secretary saying that he has set up an information office and has asked the staff who were already in the accommodation available to provide a new information service in addition to the already onerous duties they had to perform?

I am not saying that. What I am saying is that a lady clerical officer operates the information centre and that, in her absence either on leave or otherwise, a clerical assistant is available to stand in. The need for those offices is quite considerable and in addition to the one in Letterkenny we have recently opened information offices in Ballina and Carlow and in Cork and Limerick. It is the intention of the Department further to expand these information offices. As the Deputy is aware, this information office was opened on 17th of last month and I can assure him that if in the light of experience either the staff or the accommodation do not prove adequate to meet the requirements the matter will be reviewed.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that a number of social welfare offices are overloaded with work and have been for some time? Where is the expansion he talks about? Is it expansion in name only? They have not got extra staff or extra accommodation. Have they got an extra telephone?
That is a separate question.

As I told the Deputy, I can assure him that if, in the light of experience, either staff or accommodation do not prove adequate to meet the requirements of the information centre the matter will be reviewed. The Deputy has so far said nothing that would indicate that that is the case.
There is no expansion.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - “Claudia” Incident.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if reports of a homing device having been placed on the Claudia are correct.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Donegan) Patrick S. Donegan
Speaker.P: Even if such information were available to me, it would not be in the public interest to disclose it.
The Minister is aware that there have been all sorts of rumours about this affair. Could he give us a little more information about the matter?

This Cabinet accept full collective responsibility for the action of each Member of the Cabinet. I would remind the Deputy of the Taoiseach's remark in reply to a supplementary question on 23rd May, 1973. He said:

I am aware of all the circumstances and what I said is that I am not prepared, in the public interest, for security reasons, to disclose anything other than the reply I have given which covers every aspect of the matter.

MainHeading.P: That reply was in connection with the Claudia incident.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that no one person is aware of all the circumstances in any particular case?
I would not comment on a hypothetical question like that. Perhaps if God is alive He might be the person.
Are you doubting it?
I am sure God is alive. He would be the Person.
asked the Minister for Local Government if any firm proposals have been submitted by Dublin Corporation for housing redevelopment in the City Quay area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) James Tully
Speaker.P: No. The Deputy, as one of the Dublin City Commissioners, should be aware that the corporation must acquire the necessary land before submitting any such proposals.
asked the Minister for Local Government if he is aware of the long delays in processing compulsory purchase orders in County Donegal; and if he will take action to expedite matters.

The statutory provisions for the compulsory acquisition of land by local authorities, which include provisions to safeguard the interests of the landowners concerned, necessarily take some time. I am not aware that there are any undue delays in regard to County Donegal.
I may add that I am considering the need for improvements in the existing compulsory purchase order procedure.

Is the Minister aware of the delay in acquisition for the purpose of extending the pier at Sladanavoopogue, Fanad? This is something that has been going on since 1969. It was held up, so far as I am aware, because of slowness in the movement of the compulsory purchase order. Is the Minister also aware that grants from Roinn na Gaeltachta to build a community centre in Fanad Gaeltacht are held up?
The Deputy is making a long speech.

I am trying to enlist the Minister's aid. Is he aware of the long delay in many cases involving compulsory purchase orders in County Donegal? He tells me he is aware of a couple of instances but I am giving him instances where there are long delays and where he could do something about speeding up the process.
There are 12 CPOs before the Department from County Donegal and neither of the two mentioned by the Deputy are on the list. Where there are hold-ups there are good reasons for them.
I am not talking about the ones on the list. I am talking about two that are not on the list. I am talking about the ones that are before the Department.
Perhaps Donegal County Council have CPOs which they have not submitted to me yet. That must be the case. They certainly are not before the Department.
Will the Minister endeavour to help speed-up these cases?
asked the Minister for Local Government if he will arrange the payment of a reconstruction grant to a person in Kanturk, County Cork (name supplied).
This grant was paid on 30th November, 1973.
asked the Minister for Local Government if he will arrange the payment of a reconstruction grant to a person in County Cork (name supplied) as payment has been under consideration for some time.
A grant of £120 has been allocated by my Department in this case and arrangements are being made to issue the grant as soon as possible.

The applicant was allocated a special second reconstruction grant of £120 on 15th December, 1971. The work was certified by the Department's inspector as satisfactorily completed on 2nd November, 1972.

In the course of his final inspection the inspector was informed by the applicant that he had made application to Cork County Council for a reconstruction grant under the scheme of grants for physically disabled persons in respect of the same work.

The reconstruction grant of £120 is now being paid. When the county council are in a position to determine the claim to the disabled person's grant an adjustment will be made with Cork County Council, if necessary.
Would the Minister take these matters up with the council in future? I have already brought this to his notice.
This one?
Yes.
I have dealt with it already. I have only been in the Department for eight months and there may be many more such cases that have been lying there for years.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - County Wicklow Compulsory Purchase Order.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government when a final decision will be made in connection with the application by Wicklow County Council for a compulsory purchase order at Ballymorris, Bray, County Wicklow.
I hope to give my decision on this order very shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Can the Minister state when this application was made?

On the 30th December, 1972, Wicklow County Council submitted the order for confirmation. There were two objections and a local inquiry was held on the 8th March, 1973. The inspector's report was furnished on the 2nd July, 1973. The hold-up has been caused by reason of there being a planning appeal involved. This planning appeal is for private housing development on the same site and there is a legal wrangle in process as to which interest has priority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that a primary school is envisaged for this site?
No. The application is for private housing development. Do not tell me that there is an application also for a primary school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: There is an application in respect of a new primary school and church and the Bray CoOperative Society propose building 20 houses there.
The Deputy is making a statement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Since the Minister is not aware that a new primary school which is required urgently in Bray because of the expanding population there——
The Deputy is expanding greatly on the subject matter of the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: Will the Minister in the light of the information I have given him, speed up the compulsory order?

I am not aware that there is any such proposal. My Department tell me that there was a planning appeal in respect of a private housing development on the same site but there is no reference to a church or school. I will give a decision on the matter before me within the next week or so.
I am calling Question No. 22.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. Murphy Mr. C. Murphy
Speaker.P: The primary school is a matter of urgency——
Will the Deputy please resume his seat?
asked the Minister for Local Government the present position regarding the proposed sewerage schemes for (1) Rossnowlagh and (2) Burtonport, County Donegal.

I approved preliminary proposals for Rossnowlagh sewerage scheme on the 10th October, 1973. Preliminary proposals for Burtonport sewerage scheme are at present under examination in my Department. I expect to be in a position to give my decision thereon soon.
asked the Minister for Local Government if a consultant engineer has yet been approved for the proposed Ballybofey-Stranorlar stage 2 sewerage scheme, County Donegal.
My approval to the appointment of a consulting engineer to prepare a preliminary report for the Ballybofey-Stranorlar sewerage scheme issued on the 5th October last.
asked the Minister for Local Government if he has received a request from Donegal County Council to sanction a tender for Burnfoot water supply scheme; and, if so, whether sanction has been granted.
A request for sanction to a tender for this scheme has not been submitted to my Department to date.
asked the Minister for Local Government whether he has sanctioned contract documents, etc. for the Manorcunningham-Corkey water supply scheme, County Donegal.
I have now sanctioned contract documents for this scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government the present position concerning Gneeneguilla sewerage scheme, County Kerry.
Kerry County Council are at present, at my request, updating their proposals for this scheme.

asked the Minister for Finance if the excise element in the price of petrol will be lowered correspondingly with the increase in the VAT element in the case of any future increase in prices permitted to the petrol companies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. R. Ryan) Richie Ryan
Speaker.P: The answer is “No”.

I thank the Minister for his courteous and helpful reply. Would he not agree that there may be further substantial increases in petrol prices between now and the time of the next budget and that these increases would cause a further increase in the inflationary spiral? Therefore, would he not adjust the rate of VAT or excise duty to compensate for this factor?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy will appreciate that if there is a reduction in oil supplies there will be a consequential reduction in revenue. In the circumstances it would be unreasonable to contemplate that the Minister for Finance should bring about a further reduction in revenue by reducing the rate of VAT. I am sure the Deputy shares with everyone else a desire that the necessary expenditure of the Government would be financed.

Would the Minister not agree that this may be a case of killing the goose that lays the golden egg in that if we overtax petrol the distribution and other costs will increase to such an extent that the whole cost of living will be affected? Possibly there are other forms of taxation that might be re-examined in these circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Deputy is suggesting that we should introduce a completely new principle in relation to VAT, that is, that as prices rise the rate of VAT should be reduced. Such a practice would not be permitted by the EEC. It would be contrary to the neutrality of taxation. While I sympathise with the objective of trying to compensate for increases in prices I must point out that, even if VAT were to be abolished in respect of oil, this would not compensate for the increases that are likely to occur having regard to the price increases indicated already.
I am not suggesting that VAT be abolished but that it be adjusted. Would the Minister not agree that the tax element in our petroleum products is greater than in other EEC countries?
We must pass on to the next question, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: I have no information to support the Deputy's suggestion but I would point out that not only is there this undesirability of loss of revenue as a consequence of the oil situation but also that the cost to the Government of operating Government vehicles will be increased so that the Government's costs would increase while revenue could decrease.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Financial Losses in Border Areas.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if, in view of the serious financial losses suffered by the business community in the border areas of County Louth and in other border areas due to the troubles in Northern Ireland, he will provide financial aid to alleviate the hardship caused.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: Because of the many factors which govern loss or profit in trading, it would not be feasible to identify or quantify the losses, if any, suffered by individual traders in border areas, or for that matter in other parts of the country as a result of the troubles in Northern Ireland. In any event the consequences to taxpayers in general could be enormous if the principle was established that the Exchequer could be obliged to make good any trading losses.
asked the Minister for Finance the price being paid in the open market for 9¾ per cent land bonds; and when a new issue of land bonds will be forthcoming.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: At present 9¾ per cent land bonds are being quoted on the Stock Exchange at £80 per cent.
The issue of new land bonds for the period commencing 1st January, 1974, is under active consideration.
asked the Minister for Finance the new rate of interest to be paid on SDA loans in view of the interest rate paid on the new national loan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The Exchequer lending rate, on which local authority housing loans are based, is at present under review and I hope to be in a position to make a decision on the matter in the near future.
Would it not be usual for the SDA rate to be 1 per cent higher than the rate at which the Government borrow the money?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: No. It will be ½ per cent higher.
But the local authority will put on another ½ per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The rate of interest payable on local authority house loans is only ½ per cent higher than the Exchequer lending rate.
Do local authorities not add another ½ per cent?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: In some cases it is only ¼ per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: The rate is only a ½ per cent higher. It is divided between the two — a ¼ per cent each.
Is the situation under active consideration with a view to increasing it to 1 per cent?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan Mr. R. Ryan
Speaker.P: No. That is malicious consideration as distinct from active consideration. If Fianna Fáil know how to reduce interest rates on a worldwide scale they ought to make this known to the international Monetary Fund and not keep the information to themselves.
If everything is so good why are things so bad?
Order. Question No. 31.

asked the Minister for Finance if he is aware of complaints that the standard of litter collection in the Phoenix Park, Dublin, has deteriorated since March, 1973; and the plans he has to remedy the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr. Kenny) Henry Kenny
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr. Kenny)
Speaker.P: Very few complaints are received about the standard of litter collection in the Phoenix Park. I am satisfied that all reasonable steps are taken to remove litter as quickly as possible.
As a result of correspondence the Parliamentary Secretary and I have had he will be aware that one gentleman who uses the park everyday has had serious complaints during the past few months.
That same gentleman has been complaining for the past seven years.
I received only one complaint from him in three-and-a-half years and I dealt with that.

The only written complaints on record during the past five years about the standard of litter collection in the Phoenix Park have stemmed from the one source. I shall not give the name of the gentleman concerned. In May, 1968, he complained directly to the park superintendent as well as to the Dublin Regional Tourism Company that litter in the form of bottles and tin cans was being allowed accumulate in the park for weeks at a time and he complained that he seldom saw more than one man collecting litter. In October, 1969 he made similiar complaints to the then Parliamentary Secretary. On both occasions the matter was investigated and his complaints were found to be unjustified. He intimated to us that the former Parliamentary Secretary was responsible for having the litter collection extended to five days a week. That was not correct because it was the superintendent of the park who made that decision.
At my instigation.
Is the Parliamentary Secretary suggesting that the man had no right to complain?

No. He has every right to complain but I have a right to defend the park superintendent. Anyone going to the park will realise that there is no litter visible there except on Monday morning and we do not work on Sunday nights in this democratic state.
I do not like the Parliamentary Secretary's sarcastic tone.
Let us drop the sarcasm and pass to the next question.
asked the Minister for Finance if he has received the result of the cost-benefit analysis in respect of Dunkellin River, County Galway; and if he will indicate when work is likely to commence.

A cost-benefit study of the drainage of the Dunkellin catchment area has not yet been undertaken. A number of other catchment areas have priority in this respect and the expert staff available for such studies is limited. At this stage I cannot indicate when drainage works can commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary's predecessor assured us that this cost-benefit analysis was already under way. I understood it was under way for the Dunkellin catchment area. Will each catchment area be done, individually or was the survey only in respect of the Maigue?

The cost-benefit survey was initiated two years ago, in 1971. Since then an inter-departmental survey team must make a cost-benefit analysis of every catchment area to be done. Dunkellin is No. 10 on the list of minor catchments. Four minor catchment areas have already been finished, three have been by-passed on uneconomic grounds and before the Dunkellin we must consider a river in Sligo, the Bonnet.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins Mrs. Hogan O'Higgins
Speaker.P: Has the Parliamentary Secretary any idea how long the analysis on the Dunkellin will take?

The experimental cost-benefit analysis on the Maigue took two years and three months to complete. From the information gleaned in that survey we can expect that any further cost-benefit surveys will be done within a period of six months.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware of the dissatisfaction expressed by the farming community in that area at the slowness of the Office of Public Works in proceeding with this scheme? In view of the fact that the people affected by this scheme are dependent mainly on farming would he not consider giving priority to the Dunkellin scheme?
The priorities were arranged by the Arterial Drainage Act of 1945. A list of priority schemes was drawn up then and this has not been changed since.

Surely that list must be out of date by now and for that reason would the Parliamentary Secretary not consider changing it? We know that the farmers in the east are just as determined as we are in the west to have drainage work carried out, but the farmers in the east have access to industrial employment while those in the west are dependent solely on their small holdings.
The Deputy is embarking on a speech.
Would the Parliamentary Secretary now consider making the Dunkellin a priority scheme?
Deputy Hussey has made a very reasonable case for the farmers of the Dunkellin area and I will give this matter considerable thought.

Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the purpose of the cost-benefit survey being initiated was because arterial drainage was very low on the priorities of moneys available from the Government? The idea was to try to improve its place in the priority list for the allocation of money.
I understand that perfectly.
This is embarking into a debate. We have already had six supplementaries.

From my point of view this is a very important question. Could the Parliamentary Secretary allay my suspicion that this whole business of a cost-benefit analysis is simply an administrative device for postponing expenditure on this very desirable project?
It could be a device but I did not initiate this. This was initiated by the Deputy's own Department. Does the Deputy now think it is a device?
I do.
There are many things we could consider as devices but what can we say about them?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Riar Tráchta i bPáirc an Fhionnuisce.
MainHeading.P: 33. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: den Aire Airgeadais an bhfuil aon dul chun cinn déanta aige maidir le riar cheart a chur ar chúrsaí tráchta i bPáirc an Fhionnuisce, Baile Átha Cliath.

Chuaigh Coimisinéirí na nOibreacha Poiblí i gcomhairle leis na húdaráis áitiúla maidir le trácht agus fadhbanna éagsúla i bPáirc an Fhionnuisce. Tá tuairimí na n-údarás sin á scrúdú ag na Coimisinéirí faoi láthair.
Go h-iondual nuair a bhíonns daoine ag scrúdú tuarascála ní bhíonn ann ach nach bhfuil siad sásta an obair a dhéanamh.
Ní “device” é seo ar chor ar bith. Táimid á scrúdú agus déanfaimid ár ndícheall na contúirtí atá in aigne an Teachta a scrúdú agus a réiteach.

Tá a fhios agam go dtuigeann an Rúnaí Parlaiminte an cheist mar feicim go minic sa pháirc an-chuid gluaisteán ar an phríomhbhóthar ansin agus chuile lá tarlaíonn tubaist de chineál éigin. Tá dualgas ar Oifig na nOibreacha Poiblí riar éigin a chur ar chúrsaí tráchta ansin.
Má tá aon ait chontúirteach ag cros-bhóthar nó ag casadh nó áit ar bith den tsaghas sin inseoidh mé don Aire é.
Cros-bhóthar Mountjoy—sin áit chontúirteach.
Tá go maith.
asked the Minister for Finance if he will give details of any proposals to replant the trees in the Phoenix Park, Dublin.
A general survey of the trees in Phoenix Park was carried out during the past year. The results of the survey are being examined at present with a view to preparing a replanting programme.
Will the Department of Lands be co-operating in this matter?
Yes. The Department of Lands and the Wild Life Service will be co-operating in this matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Clare Drainage Schemes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance when it will be possible to carry out a comprehensive drainage scheme for the Bunratty River, County Clare.

The Bunratty—also known as Owenogarney—River is part of the Sixmilebridge catchment. This has been recorded for treatment under the Arterial Drainage Act, 1945, but because of many other urgent commitments and the limited financial and other resources I cannot at this stage say when it can be reached in the drainage programme.
Can the Parliamentary Secretary say what place this river occupies on the priority list?
It is 21 on the priority list.

asked the Minister for Finance when it will be possible to carry out a comprehensive drainage scheme in the Cooraclare-Doonbeg catchment area, County Clare; and the present position of this catchment area on the list of rivers for drainage under the Arterial Drainage Act, 1945.
asked the Minister for Finance if, in view of the serious flooding which has taken place on the Cloone River, Cranny, County Clare, he will indicate the steps he proposes to take to drain this river.
asked the Minister for Finance the present position of the Cloone River catchment area on the list of priority catchment areas for drainage under the Arterial Drainage Act, 1945.
With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 36, 37 and 38 together.

While the need for drainage in smaller catchments is appreciated, the best use can be made of available resources and the national drainage problem more quickly resolved by concentrating on the catchments included in the settled priority lists which have been upheld by successive Governments.

MainHeading.P: The Cloone and Cooraclare-Doonbeg catchments are not included on the priority lists. I regret, therefore, that I cannot say when these catchments may be reached in the arterial drainage programme.

Speaker.P: Would the Parliamentary Secretary consider putting these on the priority list?
They will take their place on this list and I will attend to that during the week. We will examine the place where we can put them but they will have to take their place in order of priority.
How soon will these schemes be completed?
I cannot give the Deputy any information about that.
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if there has been any undue delay in the making of payments to farmers for brucellosis reactors; and, if so, the reason for such delay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton) Mark A. Clinton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Clinton)
Speaker.P: The extension of compulsory measures for the eradication of brucellosis to Counties Clare and Galway in July, 1973, added considerably to the work of the local district veterinary offices and resulted in some arrears of work at the offices concerned over the past few months. Additional staff has been recruited to deal with the situation and every effort is being made to ensure that payments for reactors are made as quickly as possible.
How long does it take to pay these people for reactors?

Normally people are paid about four weeks after the reactors are found. It takes a couple of weeks to get valuation and an agreement on the valuation and to get the animals moved. After that it takes a couple of weeks more to process the application for payment through the usual channels.
Is the Minister aware that some people are waiting three months for payment?
I am not so aware but if the Deputy gives me details of any such cases I will have them investigated.

Does the Minister accept that because of his approval for an additional seven persons on the staff of the office of the Department in Ennis there will be now an immediate speeding up on the backlog of work which has accumulated?
Yes.
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the position regarding the future of the Land Project.

Financial assistance for land improvement and drainage work will continue to be available on much the same lines as heretofore. The levels of grant aid which will apply are still being discussed with the EEC Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will clarify the future position concerning subsidies for lime, potash and other fertilisers.

There is no subsidy on lime as such but the cost of transport of ground limestone from the manufacturer to the farmer is subsidised. The only fertiliser which is subsidised is phosphate. The question of the removal of these subsidies has not come up for consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the efforts his Department is making to test (a) the quality, (b) the standard, and (c) the weight of lime delivered to farmers.

The quality and standard of ground limestone intended for agricultural purpose are statutorily prescribed. Officers of my Department continually take samples of ground limestone from consignments in transit for analysis by the State Laboratory to ascertain whether they meet the statutory requirements.

Officers of my Department and inspectors of Córas Iompair Éireann make random check weighings of consignments in transit. In general these checks indicate a tendency towards overweight rather than underweight in such consignments.

asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he has received an estimate for repairs to the pier and boatslip at Port, Inver, County Donegal; and if these urgently needed repairs will be undertaken soon.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. M.P. Murphy) Michael Pat Murphy
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. M.P. Murphy)
Speaker.P: The answer is no. The maintenance of the structures referred to is the responsibility of the Donegal County Council and if repairs are required they are matters for the attention of the county council. However, I might mention that proposals for the improvement of the landing facilities at this centre are being examined at present by my Department but I am not yet in a position to say what, if any, improvement works may be approved for execution.
Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that the Office of Public Works have passed on the result of their survey of this landing place? Would he tell us what his reaction to that report was?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: We got that report. We have asked for another report from BIM. We are awaiting a report from them. When that report is available the project will be examined again in conjunction with the report we have from the OPW.
You could do better than that. You could speed it up.

asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if he will enforce the regulation introduced by the Galway Fishery Board that any trout caught which are less than 12 inches in length must be put back into the water.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is no doubt referring to a proposal by my Department that a bye-law be made fixing 12 inches as the minimum legal size of trout to be taken in Loughs Corrib, Mask and Carra. Details of this proposal were published in the Western People and the Connaught Tribune in the week ended 17th November, 1973, with a view to giving any person opposed to the proposal an opportunity to lodge an objection.

As the latest date for receipt of objections has not yet arrived a final decision in the matter has not been taken. Should I decide to make a bye-law in this matter it would be for the Galway Board of Conservators to enforce its provisions.
If the Parliamentary Secretary decided to make a bye-law in this regard in relation to the particular lakes mentioned, would he consider making similar bye-laws for other trout-fishing areas?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: If application for such bye-laws is made, the matter will be examined on its merits. This refers to three particular lakes.
asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries the extent to which Irish sea fishing has been curtailed as a result of the oil shortage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that the curtailment of Irish sea fishing as a result of the oil shortage has been negligible.

This is the herring fishing season at Dunmore East. Suppliers of oil to the fishing vessels there have been informed that their quota for December is cut by 10 per cent. Could anything be done in this case?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I do not think the Deputy's statement is correct.
On Tuesday of this week before I left to come to Dublin I was so informed by the supplier himself.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: BIM say they are not aware of any significant curtailment of fishing activities due to oil shortage. A special department has been set up by the board to deal with complaints. All fishermen's associations and co-operatives have been advised to this effect. BIM have this special department. Complaints were received from a small number of fishermen's associations last week by BIM and the Department. They referred to Cahirciveen and Galway and not to Waterford. The complaints were referred to the oil companies. It is understood that any temporary disruption which fishermen had experienced was rectified. The Deputy can be assured that the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries are watchful of this question and are taking the necessary steps to ensure that there will be no disruption.
The man I was speaking to operates the co-operative at Dunmore East. He is a private supplier.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: If the Deputy has complaints perhaps he will send them to me.

I did not catch everything the Parliamentary Secretary was saying. Is he indicating to the House that special arrangements are to be made to ensure an adequate supply of fuel to the owners of fishing trawlers? Are special arrangements being made to ensure this?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: I am indicating that BIM are setting up a special department and I myself and my Department are watching the position carefully. If any fisherman has difficulty and lets us know about it, we will do our best. I can only speak for fisheries. I cannot speak for the Minister for Transport and Power. We are getting complete co-operation from his Department whenever it is necessary to make representations. Deputy Molloy need not be worried. The position is being watched carefully.
Is the report which I saw in the newspapers to the effect that the entire fleet in Burtonport was tied up for one or two days incorrect?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: My information is that that would be incorrect. We had a report from Burtonport and it was referred to the oil company in question.

The Parliamentary Secretary must be aware that the largest fishing port in Ireland, Killybegs, is gravely disrupted? The fishermen there are perturbed by the lack of any arrangement to give them an assurance of supply?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: This must be quite recent. BIM are carrying out a port-to-port survey on the entire fishing fleet. No complaints were received from fishermen with regard to the current supplies. We have not received complaints from any Deputies who have put down questions here or asked supplementary questions. If they let us know about the complaints we will do our best.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: There is some concern also in Castletownbere, Cahirciveen and Dingle.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.P. Murphy Mr. M.P. Murphy
Speaker.P: We had a report from Cahirciveen. We had a few complaints. They were from Burtonport, Cahirciveen and Galway. BIM are doing a port-to-port survey.
Individual Deputies seem to have discovered a lot of complaints which the Parliamentary Secretary owned up to after being questioned about them.
asked the Minister for Labour the number of privately owned employment bureaux operating in the country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. M. O'Leary) Michael O'Leary
Speaker.P: The number of employment agencies which have been licensed, or have applied for licences, under the Employment Agency Act, 1971, is 91.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Airport Rescue and Security Services.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the amount of the grant made available by AnCO to Aer Rianta for the purpose of training persons in the rescue and security services at each of the airports at Dublin, Shannon and Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: AnCO have not made grants to Aer Rianta for the training of persons for the purposes mentioned.
asked the Minister for Labour if he will intervene in the dispute at a factory (name supplied) in Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I understand that the Labour Court have arranged to hear this dispute on Thursday, 20th December. In the circumstances it would not be appropriate for me to intervene.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Will the Minister tell us if he has intervened personally in any of the many disputes that have taken place throughout the country?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Coilíneachtaí Gaeilge.
MainHeading.P: 49. D'fhiarfraigh

Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachtat an bhfuil aon ghníomh á dhéanamh aige maidir le coilíneachtaí taobh amuigh den Ghaeltacht.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Gaeltacht (Mr. O'Donnell) Thomas G. O'Donnell
Speaker.P: Ní go maith a thuigim an cheist. Má léiríonn an Teachta céard tá ar intinn aige tig liom an scéal a bhreithniú.

An bhfuil a fhios ag an Aire go bhfuil daoine i mBaile Átha Cliath, i gCorcaigh agus i mBéal Feirste atá ag iarraidh a gcuid oibre a dhéanamh as Gaeilge, agus an nglacfadh sé go bhfuil dualgas air féin agus ar an Roinn suim faoi leith a chur sna daoine seo?

Admhaím go bhfuil daoine mar sin i mBaile Átha Cliath agus i gCorcaigh ach ní bhfuair mé aon mholtaí ina dtaobh go dtí seo. Más maith leis an Teachta, beidh mé sásta suim a chur in aon mholadh atá aige ina dtaobh.

Tá áthas orm go bhfuil an tAire sásta rud éigin a dhéanamh do na daoine seo. Ag an Oireachtas i mbliana bhí daoine mar sin agus níor chuir éinne suim iontu. Curirfidh méscéal chuige faoin cheist sin ar fad.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Cúrsaí Samhraidh.
MainHeading.P: 50. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an mbeadh sé sásta deontas ar leith a thabhairt do bhean tí sa Ghaeltacht nach mbeadh thar cheathrar scoláire aici aon tráth áirithe le linn na gcúrsa£ samhraidh.

MainHeading.P: 51. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an iarrfaidh sé ar lucht na gcúrsaí samhraidh gan a cheadú go mbeadh an iomad scoláirí ag cur fúthu i dteach ar bith.
Le do cheadsa, a Cheann Comhairle, tógfaidh mé Ceisteanna 50 agus 51 le chéile.

Faoi Scéim na bhFoghlaimeoirí Gaeilge is í mo Roinnse a leagann amach uaslíon na ndaltaí is ceadaithe a ghlacadh i dtithe Gaeltachta. Ní bhíonn níos mó ná ceathrar i gceist ach amháin nuair a bhítear sásta gur féidir freastal orthu agus ní dóigh liom gur chóir deontas eile fós a thabhairt chun an líon ceadaithe a laghdú i gcásanna mar sin.

Nach féidir an freastal seo a rinne an tAire tagairt dó a dhéanamh ar líon tí ina mbeidh níos mó ná cheithre páistí iontu? Séard atá mé ag smaoineamh air ná níos mó airgid a chur ar fáil do bhean an tí sna cásana sin.

Admháin go bhfuil pointe ag an Teachta ach, mar is eol dó, bhí ceist agam uaidh coichís ó shin ar an ábhar céanna. Dúirt mé leis gur bhuail mé le Comhchoiste na gColáistí Samhraidh. Phlé muid a lán ceisteanna a bhaineann leis na cúrsaí samhraidh. Thug an comhchoiste moltaí dom agus tá na moltaíseo faoi scrúdú agam agus ag an Roinn. Tá sé ar intinn agam cruinniú a bheith agam leis an gcomhchoiste go luath arís chun comhrá a bheith againn faoin scrúdú a bhéanta agam ar a gcuid moltaí.
An nglacfaidh an tAire go mba cheart dó, b'fhéidir, caint a bheith aige leis na tuismitheoirí?
Admhaím go bhfuil deacrachtaí in áiteanna áirithe, ach níl mé sásta go bhfuil sé riachtanach an scéim a leasú. Mar is eol don Teachta, tá daoine ann nach bhfuil sásta leis an scéim mar atá sé.

Tar éis an cruinniú a bhí ag an Aire leis an gcomhchoiste, an bhfuil sé sásta go bhfuil an iomarca daltaí i dtithe éigin agus i gcás mar sin go mba cheart níos mó a íoc le bean an tí mar sin? Ar phlé sé an cheist sin leis an gcomhchoiste?
Mar adúirt mé, tá an scéim faoi scrúdú agam agus ag an Roinn agus sílim nach ceart dom níos mó a rá faoi go dtí go mbeidh cruinniú eile agam leis an gcomhchoiste.
Ar chuir an comhchoiste in iúl don Aire an imní atá orthu go mbeidh laghdú mór ar an líon dalta an samhradh seo chugainn agus an bhfuil aon phlean aige chun a chinntiú nach dtarlódh sé sin?
Níl sé ar intinn agam níos mó a rá anois go dtí go mbeidh an scrúdú atá dá dhéanamh agam críochnaithe.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - Labhairt na Gaeilge.
MainHeading.P: 52. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta arbh fhiú dó, ina thuairim, dul i gcomhairle le daoine a bheadh ag triall chun na Gaeltachta go sealadach nó go seasta chun iad a ghríosú maidir le labhairt na Gaeilge.

Is é mo mhian gurb í an Ghaeilge a bheidh á labhairt ar fud na Gaeltachta agus tá mo dhícheall á dhéanamh agam chun an tábhacht a bhaineann leis sin a léiriú do dhaoine a bhíonn ag triall ar an nGaeltacht. Ní dóigh liom, áfach, go mbeadh sé indéanta agam dul i gcomhairle leis na daoine sin go léir.

B'fhéidir go mb'fhiú don Aire, nuair a bhéas daoine ag dul chun cónaite sa Ghaeltacht, billeoigín nó litir bheag a chur chucu á rá leo go bhfuil áthas ort go bhfuil said anois sa Ghaeltacht agus ag iarraidh orthu Gaeilge a labhairt chomh fada agus is féidir leo fhaid atá siad sa Ghaeltacht.
Admhaím nach raibh a fhios agam gur gá é sin a dhéanamh. An é atá i gceist ag an Teachta go gcuirfí amach leabhrán, leabhar beag nóo iris nó rud éigin mar sin?
Litir do dhaoine nua atá ag teacht chun cónaithe go seasta sa Ghaeltacht.
Sé sin, gach duine a théann chun cónaithe sa Ghaeltacht nó ar a laetheanta saoire?
Ní h-ea; go seasta, go buan.
Go seasta?
Sea. An bhféachfaidh an tAire isteach sa scéal?
O.K.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. - County Donegal Lands.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he will expedite the acquisition of land for forestry in the Ballyshannon and Pettigo areas, County Donegal and so avert redundancy in the work force in the New Year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Lands (Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick, Cavan) Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Cavan): I can assure the Deputy that all possible steps are being taken to expedite acquisition of land for afforestation in the areas to which his question refers. Some redundancies are, however, inevitable in the months ahead and the Forest and Wildlife Service will be depending on the anticipated acquisitions to maintain employment at the reduced levels.
Is the Minister aware that some land that has been acquired is available? If it were put into the development operation it might avert some of the redundancy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am aware that in the Pettigo-Lettercran area the price has been agreed. In one case the area involved is 833 acres and another vendor is expected to agree to the sale of 100 acres. Apart from these cases, price agreements have been reached in nine small cases which are with the Chief State Solicitor for title clearance. Everything possible is being done in connection with this matter.

The Minister may not have the information now but I wrote some time ago suggesting a scheme of forestry walks for the Pettigo area similar to those being carried out in other areas. Perhaps an amenity scheme similar to the one near Boyle might be considered?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I have not that information but I will look into the matter. The Rockingham scheme near Boyle is a major forest park.

asked the Minister for Lands the date on which a 31-acre holding (details supplied) was acquired by the Land Commission at Killaghtee and Bogside, County Donegal; whether it was acquired from the original owner or from a person who had purchased it after the Land Commission had initiated proceedings; and if he is aware that a young local farmer had purchased the holding before the proceedings were completed but was not allowed to complete the transaction.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Possession of the property referred to passed to the Land Commission on 2nd March, 1973.

MainHeading.P: The proceedings were taken in the name of the person who appeared to be the owner at the time and who was stated to have purchased the lands some time previously. Before the matter was finalised an application for consent to the sale of the lands to a local farmer was considered by the Land Commission but refused because of acute congestion in that district.

Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that this is an area in which the congestion problem could not be sustained in that the person in question who regards himself as the legitimate purchaser of the land is a man well qualified to receive land and has no means other than the temporary accommodation he has at the moment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I regret the information at my disposal does not bear out what the Deputy has said. It appears the land in question was sold by the original owner in June, 1971. An inspection notice was served on 3rd September, 1971, proceedings commenced for acquisition of the land on 3rd December, 1971, and the provisional list was published on 26th January, 1972. On 18th February, 1972, an application was made on behalf of the person in whom, I think, the Deputy is interested; that application was fully considered but was refused on 24th May, 1972.

MainHeading.P: The information before me, which deals with a transaction long before I became Minister for Lands, shows that the inspectors investigated fully the Deputy's constituent. It was revealed that the person in question was a landless man, living with his wife and two young children on a 42-acre holding owned by his brother-in-law. It was revealed he had three cows, four two-year-old cattle and 50 sheep on the lands situated in the townland of Tawneygorm, Inver, some five miles from the land which is mentioned in this question. The information on the file shows that the person worked full-time as a lorry driver in the town of Dunkineely. The inspector's report of May, 1972, showed he was not a suitable purchaser. The report also showed there were five worthy congests in the immediate vicinity. That is all the information I have on the file.

Speaker.P: I do not like to bring the matter to a personal level, but is the Minister aware that the applicant informed me that the Minister told him personally if he were Minister at the time he would have seen to it that he got the land?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): That is news to me. I have no recollection of meeting the man in question unless, perhaps, he called on me in Cavan. Is that correct?
That may be.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Accompanied by someone else?
Perhaps it was in Monaghan?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): It was not in Monaghan. It may have been in Cavan some months ago. Certainly I could not have told him any such thing then because I had not access to the files and did not know the particulars of the case.
Is it not the case that the Minister does not interfere in the matter of land allocation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Of course that is so and I have said that in the House. The statutory authority for acquisition and allocation of land rests with the lay commissioners. If the Minister had authority to give a direction or to allocate land in a case such as this, the Deputy would have been in a fairly strong position when this transaction was taking place.
As the Minister can see from the file, I did all I could but I was not successful.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I can see that, assisted by a few others.
asked the Minister for Lands the price payable for land purchased by the forestry section of his Department in (a) County Wexford and (b) the remainder of the country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The average price per plantable acre payable by the Forest and Wildlife Service of my Department in respect of lands for which price agreement was reached in the past year was £19 in County Wexford and £17 in the remainder of the country.
Would the Minister not agree that one of the reasons there is such a decline in forestry land at the moment is because of the poor price being paid?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I have come to the conclusion that the principal trouble is that it is not now considered that any land is suitable for planting. It is not now considered there is such a thing as bad land. The whole pressure is on the Department of Lands to release land for grazing which they have acquired for afforestation. The increased value of land and the increased profit from agricultural activities have created this problem.
Would the Minister agree or disagree that the price of £19 per acre is totally inadequate, even for poor land?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Of course the price of £19 per acre is an average taken for the whole country.
I understood the Minister to say that it was £19 in Wexford and £17 in the remainder of the country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Even in County Wexford where there is not much land on offer, that includes the worst and the best types of land. The Department of Lands are paying as much as £60 or £70 per acre. I agree that even that is not sufficient to encourage people to sell land to the forestry section. The question arises regarding the economics of paying more for land and planting. This problem has arisen in the last 12 months or two years because of the increased price for land and it is a matter on which a policy decision will have to be taken in the near future.
asked the Minister for Lands the average price paid for land in County Wexford in each of the past three years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): In accordance with the terms of section 5, Land Act, 1950, the Land Commission are required to pay the market value for lands acquired by them.

Having regard to the many factors affecting the price of individual properties such as size and quality, condition and character of dwellinghouse and farm buildings, proximity to fairs and markets, availability of amenities and other such considerations an overall average price figure for land acquired by the Land Commission in any one year has little real significance. However, if it is helpful for the Deputy the following are the overall average prices per acre paid for lands compulsorily acquired or voluntarily purchased by the Land Commission in County Wexford in the last three financial years:
I should, perhaps, say that while these figures relate to lands taken over in the years mentioned the prices may well have been agreed upon or fixed quite some time before.

My main reason for putting down this question was that at present the prices which land bonds are making on the open market are completely unfair and ridiculous. Where the Land Commission acquire land compulsorily £100 brings in something in the region of £80. That does not take into consideration what it costs to sell them. When they come back on the market they are down to £75 per £100.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): That appears to be a sepreate question.
If the Minister wants to get out of it that way I will take it up with him again after the recess.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Although he did not ask me I can tell the Deputy that as I said the prices which I have just given were prices for land taken over in the years in question and they may have been fixed previously, but the Deputy might like to know that prices actually agreed upon and fixed for the years mentioned in Wexford averaged in 1970-71 £120 per acre, 1971-72, £175 per acre, and 1972-73, £344 per acre.
Would the Minister like to comment on my remarks about land bonds?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Perhaps there would not be a lot of difference between the Deputy's thinking on land bonds and the Minister's thinking on land bonds?
Does the Minister agree then that he should make more money available for the purchase of land rather than land bonds?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Deputy may take it that I will do everything I possibly can to make it as attractive as possible for farmers to sell land to the Land Commission.
asked the Minister for Lands the amount of land in the possession of the Land Commission in County Wexford; and the amount of land divided in the last six months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The total area at present in possession of the Land Commission in County Wexford is 3,350 acres, approximately. In the last six months, a period which excluded the peak allotment time, the area divided in the county was about 45 acres. In the period from 1st April, 1973, to date, some 227 acres were total allotment figure for the full year allocated and it is expected that the ending 31st March, 1974, will be in the region of 800 acres.

Is there any way in which the Minister could speed up the division of land? Many people are under the impression that they hold on to it to get money out of it by letting it for conacre. Does the Minister agree that the average delay is three years before any farm is divided and is there any way that he can get around that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I agree that in many cases the delay is too great. The matter is under consideration in my Department at the moment with a view to expediting the allocation of land. I thoroughly agree that it is desirable that land, once acquired should be allocated with the minimum delay.
asked the Minister for Lands if the Land Commission intend carrying out a restructuring programme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): As the Deputy is aware, the Land Commission have long been engaged in a movement whose primary aim has been the improvement of the land holding pattern in the case of sub-standard units. This many sided programme includes migration, rearrangement and enlargement.

From now on these will be supplemented by measures arising from the EEC directives particularly that to encourage the cessation of farming and the re-allocation of utilised agricultural area for the purpose of structural improvement. In effect this will be the source of land supply for development farmers under the modernisation programme.
Does the Minister not feel that the Land Commission with their present limited format and special terms of reference are inadequate to meet the needs of the present day as presently constituted?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): At the moment I am in the process of making a study of the existing procedures in the Land Commission with a view to seeing how they can be improved or modernised and brought up-to-date.

asked the Minister for Lands if he has any plans to enable the inhabitants of Inishturk Island, County Mayo to live on the mainland; and, if so, if he will indicate (a) where lands and housing are to be provided and (b) when this operation is likely to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): There are at present no proposals to provide assistance to enable the inhabitants of Inishturk, County Mayo, to settle on the mainland.

I am afraid the Minister's answer is not in line with a reply I received from his colleague, the Minister for Transport and Power, who told me when I put down a question asking to have the electricity supply extended to Inishturk Island that there were plans to have the people of Inishturk taken to the mainland.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I was not aware of that answer and I am sure it is perfectly correct. As the Deputy may know, plans to assist islanders to move to the mainland are not initiated by the Department of Lands but by the central development committee which comes under the Department of Finance. If the islanders would like assistance to move to the mainland, they should approach the central development committee and the best way to do that is through the local development team.
Is this a new departure? I was of the opinion that the Land Commission arranged holdings for people being taken from islands to the mainland.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Land Commission act as agents when a decision has been taken by the central development committee. It is like a county council acting as the agent in certain rural improvement schemes.

Is the Minister aware of the grave dissatisfaction of the islanders of Inishturk and Inishturbot in County Galway who have been offered a certain amount of assistance which is totally inadequate to meet their needs?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.
I know it is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: If the Deputy knows it is a separate question he should not ask it.
I am asking the Minister to review the financial aid which is inadequate. No progress at all has been made in establishing holdings on the mainland for these residents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Deputy Molloy put down a question about that previously. If my memory serves me correctly he had it adjourned on a number of occasions. Finally when it was reached he did not find it possible to be here. I am sure he had some other——
That is irrelevant. I did not happen to be in Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The whole discussion is irrelevant. Question No. 60.
I was so interested in the question that I asked to have it adjourned. That was very small-minded of the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): If the Deputy communicates with me either by question or letter I will deal with it.
I thought the Minister would be interested to know that the amount he provided is unsatisfactory to the islanders. It would not shift the asses' carts never mind the islanders.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): If the Deputy puts down a question I will answer it and if he is here we can deal with it.
If the Minister was interested in it he would know about it. He should look it up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Deputy would not have thought of it but but for the fact that Deputy Gallagher put down another question.
That is not so.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: Question No. 60.

asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware of the hardships caused to many farmers in County Galway resulting from the large number of fragmented holdings; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The objective of land settlement policy is the improvement of farm structure; and that includes not alone the enlargement of small holdings but also the rearrangement of holdings which are held in rundale or intermixed plots. In County Galway, as elsewhere, the Land Commission carry out such rearrangement wherever they find it possible and practicable to do so. These operations, of course, always involve the surrender of plots or fields by individual farmers in exchange for other lands: the procedure is entirely voluntary; and success, therefore, depends on the willingness of all concerned to give up the plots required for the rearrangement scheme and to accept in exchange the land which the Land Commission are able to offer them.
Since 1950 approximately 2,450 holdings have been rearranged in County Galway.

Is the Minister aware that there is still a very serious problem in Galway in connection with fragmented holdings and could he tell me if the Land Commission are prepared to initiate any new schemes designed to speed up the restructuring of these holdings?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am aware that there is a problem in Galway and, indeed, in many other counties. I am informed that it is particularly bad in Galway. The solution to the problem requires the goodwill and co-operation of the various people affected because, if one is going to close gaps, one inevitably has to move people. The officers of my Department are available for consultation with the local people interested. I would suggest that the local advisory services might be availed of to encourage a local plan which would lead to people being agreeable to co-operate in the rearrangement of holdings. From what I have seen and from what I have been told I am convinced that, without goodwill on the part of those concerned, the problem is almost impossible of solution.

asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on this country's present position vis-à-vis the Arab states; and if he has had any recent confirmation from those states in regard to Ireland's position in the present oil crisis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Ryan (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs) Mr. R. Ryan (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs)
Speaker.NameTxt: Mr. R. Ryan (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs)
Speaker.P: Ireland's position is that we have always maintained friendly relations with the states of the Arab world. There have been no indications that the Arab states regard our position as being in any way other than friendly. The Government have consistently supported the efforts of the Secretary-General of the United Nations and the decisions of the Security Council designed to achieve a just and lasting settlement to the conflict in that area. Ireland's individual contribution to the search for this settlement has taken the concrete form of making available, at the request of the Secretary-General, a contingent of Irish troops to serve with the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middle East to assist in the implementation of Security Council resolutions.

As the House will be aware, the Arab states have felt obliged to take certain decisions in regard to the production and supply of oil. My understanding is that the Arab states intend to make known comprehensively their attitude to the rest of the world in the matter of oil supplies. This has not yet been done.
